definition: ill-gotten wealth or gains
(negative prefix)/not/no
justice/righteousness/meaning/foster (father etc)/adopted/artificial (tooth, limb etc)/relationship/friendship
surname Yi/(Tw) abbr. for 義大利|义大利[Yi4 da4 li4], Italy
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
money/wealth/riches/property/valuables

sentences.english: He therefore thought that the use of their negligence, earn ill- gotten gains.
sentences.chinese: 於是他就想到，利用他們的疏忽，賺取不義之財。

sentences.english: Never use the terms “filthy lucre” or “I despise money.”
sentences.chinese: 永遠不要使用詞語“不義之財”或“我鄙視金錢。”

sentences.english: The bank robbers went to Brazil to live on their ill-gotten gains.
sentences.chinese: 那些銀行搶竊者們到巴西去拿不義之財生活。

sentences.english: Treasures gained by wickedness do not profit, but righteousness delivers from death.
sentences.chinese: 不義之財毫無益處，唯有公義能救人脫離死亡。

sentences.english: While millions were fighting and dying, the profiteers were lining their pockets.
sentences.chinese: 數百萬人在打仗捐軀，而奸商們卻趁機發不義之財。

sentences.english: Tana accused the west of the father is the man stealing other peoples wealth.
sentences.chinese: 塔納指責西瓦的父親是偷竊別人的不義之財的人。

sentences.english: He escaped to South America with his ill-gotten gains .
sentences.chinese: 他帶着不義之財逃往南美。

sentences.english: He despises ill-gotten wealth, but does not absolutely despise interests.
sentences.chinese: 他拒絕不義之財，又不絕對重義輕利。

sentences.english: He that is greedy of gain troubleth his own house.
sentences.chinese: 貪愛不義之財的禍害自己的家。

definition: harming others for one's personal benefit (idiom); personal gain to the detriment of others
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
tip/gratuity/monetary reward/bonus
petty crime/misdemeanor
to kill sb for his property (idiom); to murder for money
Trouble issues from the mouth (idiom). A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.
to plot and kill sb for his property (idiom); to murder for money
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
shameful secret
making a deer out to be a horse (idiom); deliberate misrepresentation
evil has its retribution (idiom); to suffer the consequences of one's bad deeds/sow the wind and reap the whirlwind (Hosea 8:7)
to deceive/to conceal
to advance prematurely
many men, a great force (idiom); many hands provide great strength/There is safety in numbers.
to gang up for personal interest (idiom)/to form a clique
